body:
I think the 2D wavelets for joint time-frequency scattering look slightly
different from the 2D ones used for images, but yes, in principle this is
the idea.

> It'd help to have this API-supported with guiding docstrings, or at least
an example of how to use Scattering1D & Scattering2D to do joint scattering.

I agree that this would be nice to have.



On Tue, Mar 2, 2021 at 4:28 PM OverLordGoldDragon <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> It is my understanding that Joint Time-Frequency Scattering
> <https://www.lostanlen.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/anden2019tsp.pdf>
> is 2D scattering with a spin up & down Morlet wavelet filterbank, time &
> frequency directions decoupled, applied on 1D scattering coefficients. If
> that's accurate, seems everything's in place to use it given properly
> configured filter_bank (think L=2 is needed).
>
> It'd help to have this API-supported with guiding docstrings, or at least
> an example of how to use Scattering1D & Scattering2D to do joint
> scattering.
>
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/kymatio/kymatio/issues/672>, or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAJ7AC662QFZGAWAXGK2NGTTBVKBRANCNFSM4YPYSSYA>
> .
>

Hello @OverLordGoldDragon (i think i know you from librosa btw!)

Thank you for this feature request. You are right in that joint time--frequency scattering (JTFS) is not supported by Kymatio in its current version. The only available implementations are in MATLAB: ScatNet or my implementation (scattering.m) https://github.com/lostanlen/scattering.m

However, as @eickenberg notes, JTFS is not as simple as stacking a layer of Scattering2D on top of a layer of Scattering1D. The 2-D filtering in JTFS should be applied to the un-averaged output of Scattering1D, noted as U1 in the research papers. This unaveraged output is multirate, and thus cannot be used as an input of Scattering2D. Instead, what is necessary is to apply 1-D filtering in time (just like in second-order time scattering) and then immediately apply 1-D filtering in frequency.

This means that it is needed to:
* design a custom filter bank for the frequency domain
* rewrite the depth-first search so that j2 appears in the *outer* loop, not the inner loop
* concatenate paths which share a common j2 along the j1 axis
* take care of the edge case where the frequency filter is a low-pass (phi) whereas the time filter is a band-pass (psi)
* implement spatiotemporal low-pass filtering at the end to ensure invariance to frequency transposition

I have short-term plans to use more JTFS in research so i'd like to captain this effort. It's far from obvious, but it's within reach. However, given the scale of the task, i think it's prematurate to envision merging this to Kymatio as soon as it's ready. I imagine that other admins (@eickenberg et al.) will prefer to see this code develop in a separate repository for the moment. Once we're satisfied with the tool, we may consider including it as part of the "standard library" of Kymatio. (and you all can be sure that i'll be ðŸ¥³ -ing that day!)

Thoughts?

I think the first step is to merge filter_bank_1d and filter_bank_2d. Joint is quite simple to implement (both-rototranslation and spiral scattering), it's really a matter of having a clean code, imho.

@OverLordGoldDragon and @lostanlen you're more than welcome to PR this! (I think @eickenberg is/was working on it too)

> I think the first step is to merge filter_bank_1d and filter_bank_2d.  

if you wish but i don't see how that relates to this issue? There's no actual 2-D filterbank in JTFS. There are three 1-D filterbanks: one for the first layer and two (time and frequency) for the second layer.

roto-translation would be great to have. Spiral is a relatively "niche" improvement on top of JTFS and does not deserve to be included (and i say this all the more comfortably that i'm the one who invented spiral scattering)

I also seek to use this in research and am willing to assist where reasonably able. I'd mainly go off of the MATLAB implementation as I couldn't extract implementation 'fine detail' from the publication (i.e. @lostanlen 's bullet points and more).

@lostanlen We've met when I was rather too new to STFT; indeed the transform's lot more invertible than I imagined. Have a plan in mind with the separate JTFS repo? A Kymatio fork or clone seems best as it contains much reusable code and should ease the subsequent merger.

Re:

 1. **2D wavelets**: right, they're not same as for images, time & frequency dimensions are treated independently, guess this also needs implementing, but I imagine some 1D logic is reusable.
 2. **Feeding Scat1D to 2D**: isn't the multirate discrepancy overcome with a sufficiently large `oversampling`? With max `oversampling` and no averaging it looks like a plain CWT; below I applied it on an exponential chirp and compared with [ssqueezepy.cwt](https://github.com/OverLordGoldDragon/ssqueezepy/blob/0.6.0/ssqueezepy/_cwt.py#L10):

<details>
  <summary>Code</summary>

```python
import numpy as np
from ssqueezepy.visuals import imshow
from ssqueezepy import cwt, TestSignals
from kymatio.numpy import Scattering1D

#%%##########################################################################
N = 2**12
tsigs = TestSignals(N=N)
x = tsigs.echirp(N)[0]

#%%##########################################################################
Wx, scales = cwt(x, ('gmw', {'beta': 90}))

#%%###########################################################################
T = x.shape[-1]
J = 11
Q = 16
scattering = Scattering1D(J, T, Q, oversampling=8, average=False,
                          vectorize=False, out_type='list')
Scx = scattering(x)

#%%###########################################################################
meta = scattering.meta()
order1 = np.where(meta['order'] == 1)
_Scx1 = np.vstack([Scx[i]['coef'] for i in order1[0] if len(Scx[i]['coef']) == N])

#%%###########################################################################
imshow(Wx,    abs=1, ticks=0, title="abs(ssqueezepy.cwt)")
imshow(_Scx1, abs=1, ticks=0, title="abs(kymatio.Scattering1D)")
```

</details>

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16495490/109844038-2937dc80-7c65-11eb-86f3-ed346bc4dbef.png)

body:
>  I imagine some 1D logic is reusable.

yes.


> Feeding Scat1D to 2D: isn't the multirate discrepancy overcome with a sufficiently large oversampling?

You're absolutely right. But without any assumption on the signal, the oversampling should be of the order of J (the number of octaves), which is going to slow down the computation and increase the memory load.

```
class TimeFrequencyScatteringTorch(ScatteringTorch1D):
    def __init__(
            self,
            J,
            shape,
            Q,
            average=True,
            oversampling=0,
            out_type="array",
            backend="torch"
        ):
        vectorize = True # for compatibility, will be removed in 0.3
        
        # Second-order scattering object for the time variable
        max_order_tm = 2
        ScatteringTorch1D.__init__(
            self, J, shape, Q, max_order_tm, average,
            oversampling, vectorize, out_type, backend)

        # First-order scattering object for the frequency variable
        max_order_fr = 1
        shape_fr = (Q * J)
        J_fr = int(math.log2(Q * J)) - 1
        Q_fr = 1
        self.sc_freq = ScatteringTorch1D(
            J_fr, shape_fr, Q_fr, max_order_fr, average,
            oversampling, vectorize, out_type, backend)
```


(feel free to propose a better name than `sc_freq`)
Ahem, maybe you can make a PR on a local fork and we can have a look on it from time to time?

> slow down the computation and increase the memory load.

Right, but I don't suppose there's a way around it, as a single 2D matrix is needed. To this end ssqueezepy's `cwt` code could be reused, vectorized or for-loop, which I'm currently optimizing for both speed and memory (already outdoes Kymatio in both). (Basically since we only do first-order and no downsampling, we do a simple matrix multiply followed by `ifft`).

@OverLordGoldDragon maybe you could try to PR your code in ours, if the speedup is significant? ASV should be supported soon when @janden or @eickenberg will have time to review the corresponding initial PR

@edouardoyallon It's significant but not kymatio-friendly; root of speedup is vectorization, which isn't very compatible with all the downsampling and alternating between first- and second-orders. Other speedup comes from allowing single precision, and `pyfftw` planning (i.e. CPU speedup).  I'm fine for porting it specifically for time-frequency scattering though.

Regarding PR: doable, can keep both a PR and separate repo copy for 'freer' commits. I'm thinking of adding `kymatio/scattering1d_joint` to contain the unique filters, utilities and such - would that work?
